stem: A client at 34 weeks gestation arrives at 1400 reporting a severe frontal headache and seeing 'dark spots.' Assessment reveals BP 172/112 and +3 proteinuria. Complete the bowtie to manage this high-risk obstetric situation.

actions.text: Initiate IV Magnesium Sulfate bolus and drip
Induce labor with high-dose Oxytocin immediately
Place client in a Trendelenburg position
Apply padding to side rails (Seizure Precautions)

rationale.correct: The client exhibits signs of preeclampsia with severe features: elevated BP (â‰¥160/110 mmHg), severe headache, visual disturbances ('dark spots'), and significant proteinuria (+3). Magnesium sulfate is the priority to prevent seizures (eclampsia). Padding side rails provides safety during potential seizure activity. Monitoring DTRs and clonus is crucial to assess for magnesium toxicity (decreased/absent reflexes) and CNS irritability. Hourly urine output and BP monitoring are essential to evaluate kidney function and the effectiveness of treatment.
rationale.incorrect: Inducing labor with oxytocin is not the immediate priority; stabilizing the mother is paramount. While delivery is the ultimate cure for preeclampsia, it's crucial to control the hypertension and prevent seizures first. Trendelenburg position is indicated for hypotension or cord prolapse, not hypertension. Cervical dilation speed and blood glucose levels are not the most critical parameters to monitor in this acute situation.
clinicalPearls: Calcium gluconate is the antidote for magnesium sulfate toxicity. Be prepared to administer if respiratory rate falls below 12 breaths/min, DTRs are absent, or urine output decreases significantly. Maintain a therapeutic magnesium level of 4-7 mEq/L.
Monitor for signs of HELLP syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets), a severe complication of preeclampsia.
Strict I&O monitoring is critical. Oliguria can indicate worsening renal function.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the immediate threat: seizure prevention. Magnesium sulfate is the first-line treatment to prevent seizures in preeclampsia with severe features. Stabilize the mother before considering delivery.

mnemonic.title: HELLP Me!
mnemonic.expansion:
H - Headache, Hypertension
E - Evaluate DTRs
L - Labs (Urine Protein, CBC, Liver Enzymes)
L - Lower BP
P - Prevent Seizures (Mag Sulfate)
Me - Monitor Everything!

Key Actions: Initiate IV Magnesium Sulfate bolus and drip; Apply padding to side rails (Seizure Precautions)
Key Monitoring: Deep Tendon Reflexes (DTRs) and Clonus; Hourly Urine Output and BP

reviewUnits.heading: Preeclampsia with Severe Features: Pathophysiology & Management
reviewUnits.body: Preeclampsia with severe features is characterized by hypertension (â‰¥160/110 mmHg), proteinuria, and signs of end-organ damage (headache, visual disturbances). The priority is to prevent seizures with magnesium sulfate and monitor for magnesium toxicity (decreased DTRs, respiratory depression). Calcium gluconate is the antidote for magnesium toxicity.

reviewUnits.heading: Magnesium Sulfate Administration
reviewUnits.body: Administer magnesium sulfate as a bolus followed by a continuous infusion. Monitor respiratory rate, DTRs, urine output, and serum magnesium levels. Have calcium gluconate readily available.
reviewUnits.source: Saunders Comprehensive Review for the NCLEX-RN Examination, 9th Edition

reviewUnits.heading: Nursing Interventions for Preeclampsia with Severe Features
reviewUnits.body: Prioritize seizure precautions (padded side rails, oxygen, suction equipment). Monitor BP, urine output, DTRs, and fetal heart rate. Administer antihypertensive medications as prescribed. Prepare for potential delivery.
reviewUnits.source: HESI Comprehensive Review for the NCLEX-RN Examination, 6th Edition
